>  institutions* in the Southern states.”**  
>  
> **“The Constitution of the United States, in its
>  original sense, guaranteed to each state the right to *hold
>  property*—including enslaved persons—without interference from
>  the Federal government.  The election of a President whose
>  declared purpose is to make that property *subject to

H. Buchanan, 1900.)*

### Why this passage matters

| Point | Explanation |
|------|-------------|
| **Explicit link to slavery** | The text states that the “systematic denial of the right … to the use of the enslaved labor” is a “most long‑continued grievance.” It does not speak of abstract “states’ rights” in isolation; the right being defended is *the right to own slaves*. |
| **Reference to the Constitution** | The declaration argues that the Constitution guarantees property (i.e., enslaved people) and that Lincoln’s anti‑expansion stance threatens that guarantee. This frames secession as a *legal* defense of property rights, not a purely political protest. |
| **Immediate cause: Lincoln’s election** | The declaration identifies the election of a president whose platform opposed the spread of slavery as the “immediate cause” of the crisis, underscoring that the political shift, not a sudden economic downturn or a foreign policy dispute, triggered the decision. |
| **Public justification** | By publishing this document, South Carolina sought both domestic and international legitimacy, presenting secession as a constitutional remedy rather than a rebellion. |

| **Alabama** (January 11 1861) – “Our economy and our very way of life depend upon the institution of slavery, which the Republican Party seeks to abolish.” |
